description: From Middle English belle, from Old English belle (“bell”), from Proto-Germanic *bellǭ. Cognate with West Frisian belle, bel, Dutch bel, Low German Belle, Bel, Danish bjelde, Swedish bjällra, Norwegian bjelle, Icelandic bjalla.

entries.meaning: A percussive instrument made of metal or other hard material, typically but not always in the shape of an inverted cup with a flared rim, which resonates when struck.
examples: HEAR the sledges with the bells —
What a world of merriment their melody foretells!

entries.meaning: An instrument that emits a ringing sound, situated on a bicycle's handlebar and used by the cyclist to warn of his or her presence.
The sounding of a bell as a signal.

examples: I’ll give you a bell later.

entries.meaning: A signal at a school that tells the students when a class is starting or ending.
(music) The flared end of a brass or woodwind instrument.
(nautical) Any of a series of strokes on a bell (or similar), struck every half hour to indicate the time (within a four hour watch)
The flared end of a pipe, designed to mate with a narrow spigot.
Anything shaped like a bell, such as the cup or corolla of a flower.

(architecture) The part of the capital of a column included between the abacus and neck molding; also used for the naked core of nearly cylindrical shape, assumed to exist within the leafage of a capital.

examples: He swam to the place where Mary disappeared but there was neither boil nor gurgle on the water, nor even a bell of departing breath, to mark the place where his beloved had sunk.

verbs.description: bell (third-person singular simple present bells, present participle belling, simple past and past participle belled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shape so that it flares out like a bell.
(intransitive) To develop bells or corollas; to take the form of a bell; to blossom.

description: From Middle English bellen, from Old English bellan (“to bellow; make a hollow noise; roar; bark; grunt”), from Proto-Germanic *bellaną (“to sound; roar; bark”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰel- (“to sound; roar; bark”). Cognate with Scots bell (“to shout; speak loudly”), Dutch bellen (“to bark”), German Low German bellen (“to ring”), German bellen (“to bark”), Swedish böla (“to low; bellow; roar”).

entries.meaning: The bellow or bay of certain animals, such as a hound on the hunt or a stag in rut.

verbs.description: bell (third-person singular simple present bells, present participle belling, simple past and past participle belled)

examples: As the dawn was breaking the Sambhur belled / Once, twice and again!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To utter in a loud manner; to thunder forth.
examples: Their leaders bell their bleating tunes In doleful sound.
